article.title: Bastard_Operator_From_Hell

template.arg: "PFY", an acronym for "Pimply-Faced Youth", redirects here. For other uses, see [[PFY (disambiguation)]]

article.paragraph: TheBastard Operator From Hell(BOFH) is afictional characterfictionalroguesystem administratorwho takes out his anger onuser (computing)users(often referred to aslusers), colleagues, bosses, and anyone else who pesters him with their computer problems. Several people have written stories about BOFHs, but the canonical one was created by Simon Travaglia.The BOFH stories were originally posted in 1992 toUsenetby Travaglia, with some being reprinted inDatamation.cite webhttp://bofh.ntk.net/BOFH/index.php The Bastard Operator from Hell Official Archive Simon Travaglia Datamation Magazine They were published weekly from 1995 to 1999 inNetwork Weekcitation neededDecember 2013and since 2000 they have been published regularly inThe Register.Simon Travaglia, The Register, accessed 18 January 2013Several books of the stories have also been released.

By extension, the term is also used to refer to any system administrator who displays (or wishes he could get away with) the qualities of the original,cite bookEric S.Raymond[[The New Hacker's Dictionary]]978-0-262-68092-91996The MIT Press80cite webhttp://arstechnica.com/security/2008/09/the-bofh-lives-88-of-it-workers-would-steal-data-if-fired/The BOFH lives: 88% of IT workers would steal data if firedPaulRyan[[Ars Technica]]2008-09-082014-12-31becoming commonInternet slang.

The early editions of the BOFH took place in a university, later moving on to an office workplace over time. The stories of 2000 (BOFH 2k) began with the BOFH and his pimply-faced youth (PFY) assistant moving to a new company.
